data.title: webview rendering performance issue for large size HTML
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write an extension to preview a large size HTML(like more than ~400KB or more) use the command `vscode.previewHtml`. The rendering time of vscode will always take more than 3 seconds(depend on the size).

I think can we improve the performance of this?

data.title: Toggle expanded docs, add stickyness to expansion
data.body:
Fixes #26282

- Docs expand only after user chooses to do so either by `Ctrl+Space` or by clicking on the "Read More" icon
- Once docs expand, they remain expanded until user chooses to close it either by `Ctrl+Space` or by clicking on the "Read less" icon
- To move focus between the list and the docs, a new Key binding `Ctrl+Alt+Space` is introduced. 

The user choice is stored in local storage to make the experience sticky.

data.title: Debug using NodeJS is resulting in vscode using "read only content from NodeJS"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:13:11.413Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Open up NodeJS project, file is in UTF-8
2. Set Debug config as 
{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "name": "Debug Function",
      "type": "node",
      "request": "attach",
      "port": 5858
    }
  ]
}
3. Run debug
4. Stop debug
5. Make code change to index.js
6. Restart debug to reproduce issue.

data.title: Theme statusBar.background doesn't work if a folder isn't open
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a folder
2. open settings, and place something like 

```
"workbench.colorCustomizations": {
        "statusBar.background": "#000000",
}
```
and the status bar will turn black  
 3. close folder  
 4. status bar turns purple, however other customizations (like  `editorLineNumber`) persists when a folder is/isn't open

data.title: Refactor TextEditorOptions.fromEditor to be a Static Method
data.body: Refactors `TextEditorOptions.fromEditor` to a static method instead of an instance method. This method is only called after creation of the options object and currently requires using a cast in a few places

data.title: Better sort of recently used items on Quick Open Menu from external folders
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:13:11.413Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-markdownlint|DavidAnson|0.7.2|
|beautify|HookyQR|1.0.2|
|alignment|annsk|0.3.0|
|npm-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.3.0|
|path-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.4.2|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.11|
|prettier-vscode|esbenp|0.17.1|
|git-project-manager|felipecaputo|1.3.2|
|flow-for-vscode|flowtype|0.6.0|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.1|
|vetur|octref|0.6.10|
|language-stylus|sysoev|1.7.2|
|vscode-react-native|vsmobile|0.3.2|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file called `app.js` that is located in an external folder to the currently opened workspace.
2. Open `app.js` that is located in the current workspace using ⌘P (quick open)
3. Now type `app` in ⌘P (quick open)

For the rest of time, the `app.js` from outside the workspace will always always show up on the top of the list. I would expect the `app.js` file that was most recently opened to be at the top, regardless if it was internal/external to the currently opened workspace.

Although those two files have the same name, they are in fact different files. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4333958/26131217/b5aecd08-3a66-11e7-879e-67a32591d986.png)

data.title: git-bash does not init .bash_profile
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:20:36.315Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|python|donjayamanne|0.3.23|
|wrap|dt|0.0.1|
|mssql|ms-mssql|0.2.1|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|0.9.0|;


---
A bash shell should run the user's `.bash_profile` to customize the shell when it's launched.  For the git-bash shell that comes with git for windows, the .bash_profile is not run. 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set git-bash as the shell that cntl-shft-` launches
2. Check a setting that ~/.bash_profile makes and note that it's missing
3. run source(~/.bash_profile) and verify that this does set the customizations. 

-jm  (joagosta@microsoft.com)

data.title: Latest Versions of Socket.io Not Listed When I Hover Over Package.json Dependencies (And No Updates Available)
data.body:
My dev environment:
OS X El Capitan 10.11.6
MacBook Air
VSC Version 1.12.2 (1.12.2)
Node: v7.4.0

We are trying update our socket.io versions in our Angular app so that they match those we're using on the server. Currently though VSC doesn't show what I know to be the the most current versions available when I hover over our dependencies in our package.json file. This is what I see:

> TypeScript definitions for socket.io
> Latest version: 1.4.29

 Also, when I click "Check for Updates", under the "Code" tab, I get "No updates are currently available". How can I ensure that when I hover over a dependency in my package.json, that VSC will actually show me the most current versions of various libraries? I tried manually entering what I know to be the most recent version of socket.io - which is "2.0.1", but then I get a compilation error.

data.title: "Find All References" throws error

- OS Version: Windows 10.

2. Right-click and select "Find All References"

data.title: Restore all open windows after a VSCode or OS restart, as is done when updates are applied.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.,2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open multiple VSCode windows.
2. Restart VSCode to apply updates, all open windows are restored.
3. Quit VSCode and re-open, or reboot, only one of the open windows are restored, should restore all windows like in #2.

This is slightly less annoying now than it was because when searching to find out if this had already been requested before, I found that the previous request of adding a setting for creating new windows at the same size of existing windows had been fulfilled, thanks for that.  Now I don't have to resize each of the 3 or 4 new windows that I have to open after a restart.

data.title: VSCode seems to be shelling out using /bin/sh and not default shell
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.4

Since updating to 1.12.x, VSCode has been struggling with finding binaries that is had no issues finding previously, as PATH is set in my default shell (`/bin/bash`) but not in `/bin/sh`.  Looking through the properties, it doesn't seem like I can set PATH or the shell used when VSCode calls other tools.

Is this a regression, or am I doing something wrong?

3. `F4`, `F4`, `Shift+F4`

data.title: Key "c" acts as DELETE key in the editor in v1.12 / v1.11
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2 / 1.11.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu Yakkety

This problem surely didn't happen in 1.10.2 when I was with it and now downgrading.

In 1.11 and 1.12 the "c" key (without holding shift, but independent of CAPS LOCK) acts as DELETE.

Ctrl+c also deletes the current character. Shift+c works.

I use Ubuntu Yakkety server in vagrant (with VirtualBox) and access it in Windows with Xpra.

I tried to remove ~/.vscode and the same problem happens.

data.title: Git: Command to stage all selected files

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

I'm not sure if this is a bug or not, but currently I'm not able to stage multiple files at a time using a keyboard shortcut. I am able to do this using the UI (by clicking the "Stage" button on one of the selected files), but not with a configured keyboard shortcut.

For example, in SourceTree I'm used to selecting a few files (by either control- or shift-clicking), then hitting the space bar to stage them. I tried adding the space bar as a shortcut for the "git.stage" command, but this will only commit a single file in the selection, not all selected files.

Steps to Reproduce:
 1. Open VS Code and configure a keyboard shortcut for the "git.stage" command
 1. Open a git project
 1. Make changes to multiple files in the project
 1. Go to the Source Control pane in the explorer
 1. Control-click or shift-click to select multiple files in the "Changes" section, then type the keyboard shortcut configured above

Expected Result: All selected files should be staged and appear in the "Staged Changes" section
Actual Result: Only the top file in the selected set is staged

Related to this, is there a context for keyboard shortcuts that is specific to when the Source Control pane of the explorer is active? I didn't see one listed in the documentation on the site.

VScode throw an error on code "try {throw new Error(); } catch (e) {......}" when launch debugger
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:1.12.2
- OS Version:win10 64

Steps to Reproduce:
Hi, I am a node.js developer from China.There is problem when I launch VScode debugger after I installed "Q" or "bluebird" module.It will stop and throw an error(Just error,nothing else info) on code "try {throw new Error(); } catch (e) {......}", The "Q" and "bluebird" have the samilar code .But if I type "Node index.js" in CMD to launch my application,It works well.
And this is the error stacks:
发生异常: Error
Error
    at Object.<anonymous> (E:\Google\Nodejs\angulr\node_modules\.3.5.0@bluebird\js\release\util.js:378:12)
    at Module._compile (module.js:570:32)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:579:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:487:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:446:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:438:3)
    at Module.require (module.js:497:17)
    at require (internal/module.js:20:19)

    at Object.<anonymous> (E:\Google\Nodejs\angulr\node_modules\.3.5.0@bluebird\js\release\bluebird.js:9:36)

1.Install Q or "bluebird" module
2.Type code "var Q=require('q')" or "var Promise = require('bluebird')"
3.launch debugger
![qq 20170516234714](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/26517950/26115455/9ea13e58-3a92-11e7-86c8-6727692f64a2.png)

data.title: Keep "untitled" files available between executions.
data.body:
I use a lot this feature in other editors like Notepad++ where your "unsaved" tabs are open between executions.

This is a great way to keep notes open while you gather information before you actually want to write a "proper" file or document.

data.title: Clinking on a completion proposal inserts different result
data.body:
- install the Java language server (Redhat)
- open code assist here
```
package com.aeschli.testapp;

public class TestHelper {

    public static <T> boolean isEquals(T t, T u) {
        return t.|<code assist here
```

- use the cursor to find `toString` press enter. All correctly inserted.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6461412/26114011/7e0b315c-3a5c-11e7-8bf9-223596670454.png)
- use the mouse and click on the `toString` proposal. This inserts more (looks like the label)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6461412/26114058/a0f85672-3a5c-11e7-8dc5-f90e22a8a303.png)

data.title: Removing Git crashes or lags the editor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:13:11.413Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|erb|CraigMaslowski|0.0.1|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.14|
|erb|Riey|0.1.1|
|ruby-on-rails-snippets|atefth|0.0.1|
|vscode-whitespacer|deerawan|1.0.0|
|LogFileHighlighter|emilast|1.1.1|
|ruby|groksrc|0.0.6|
|ruby-linter|hoovercj|1.0.0|
|ruby-rubocop|misogi|0.3.5|
|prettify-json|mohsen1|0.0.3|
|Ruby|rebornix|0.12.1|
|simple-ruby-erb|vortizhe|0.2.0|;

---

Removing Git from a REPO causes all files in the filesystem to load in the github tab, and the editor to lag or crash.  

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have a git repo that has a ruby script that removes git (( This is what I'm using `FileUtils.rm_r "../.git"`))
2. Copy the repo and open in in vscode
